repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Community Works Project, Second
            Community Works Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community Works Project
            for Albania were as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Second Community Works Project for Albania were as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: a
            demand-driven approach may not guarantee that the highest
            community priorities are met unless steps are taken to
            ensure a robust and inclusive participatory process and to
            prevent demand distortion that can result from, for example,
            requests for goods and services that are perceived to be
            easiest to obtain (e.g., roads in this case) rather than
            those that may be most wanted. Capacity building cannot be
            treated as a by-product; explicit mechanisms will generally
            be needed to build appropriate and lasting capacity. In
            projects with multiple objectives requiring different staff
            skills-mixes for their implementation, up-front clarity
            about the relative emphasis to be placed on the various
            objectives is critical, especially in capacity-constrained
            contexts. Trade-offs among objectives need to be watched
            closely, and addressed. Building capacity in local
            governments and communities is time- and human
            resource-intensive, making disbursements potentially slower
            and less predictable than when infrastructure delivery is
            the primary focus. The performance incentives, staffing, and
            skills-mix of the project implementation unit will need to
            match the project's primary focus. In the case of
            Albania, Albanian Development Fund (ADF) maintained an
            engineering orientation in its staffing and processes,
            building infrastructure much more successfully than building
            capacity. In projects with multiple objectives, each of
            which requires a different staff skill mix for its
            implementation, up-front clarity about the relative emphasis
            to be placed on the various objectives is critical. The
            roles and responsibilities of the various institutions that
            the project will relate to need to be clarified in project
            design it, and project design also needs to envision and
            factor in the longer-term role of any autonomous project
            implementation unit.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall rating of the project
            outcome is satisfactory, and project sustainability is
            likely. world Bank and Borrower performances are rated
            satisfactory. This report identifies the factors for the
            project's success as: 1) strong country ownership; 2)
            the professional and personal commitment of staff at both
            the Bank and the Albanian Development Fund (ADF); and 3) the
            commitment of the donor community at large to continue
            supporting ADF activities in future operations. The
            highlighted difficulties concern the infrasructure works,
            local government and community capacity building, social
            services delivery, governance, donor coordination, and
            project management. For instance, rursl roads, water supply,
            and sewerage sub-projects have created noticeable benefits,
            but in many cases, sub-projects cannot serve the whole
            community due to over-design or because this would result in
            exceeding the permitted financial limits. Both issues could
            be resolved by carrying out a cost-benefit analysis for each
            sub-project and by formally requesting to exceed the
            ceiling. Alternatively, the financial limits of the
            sub-projects could be revised. Another possibility would be
            to leave financial limits as they are, but sub-projects
            could be smaller in scope. Although significant progress has
            been made by the ADF in dealing with local governments,
            there is still a disconnect between the ADF Charter and
            reality on the ground. The institutional and Managerial
            Review suggests revising ADF's Charter. A much stronger
            poverty targeting, both geographically and by typology of
            infrastructure, should be sought in the follow-on project.
            The current criteria "one commune, one project"
            could no longer be justified in light of the GPRS process
            and a better poverty impact analysis of individual
            sub-projects should be carried out. Regarding social
            services delivery, the experience of ADF has been mixed and
            generally there is room for improvement. The recent
            "Institutional and Managerial Review" suggests
            that ADF should probably drop the Social Services and
            concentrate first on excellence in infrastructure projects.
            ADF could even become an implementing agent or subcontractor
            agent for the infrastructure component of other projects,
            including social programs. In regard to governance, ADF
            should be better protected from political presssures, and
            there is a need to bring the Board closer to the local
            level; room needs to be made for representatives of
            communes/municipalities and the twelve Qarks, as well as for
            local communities. conflicting procedures have caused
            confusion among ADF staff, bidders, and beneficiaries;
            efforts to strengthen donor coordination should ideally
            include both procurement and contracting issues. With
            respect to project management, issues that still need to be
            tackled include updating the terms of reference and job
            description of ADF staff, particularly the social
            inspectors; devising a staff training program; and
            formalizing the yearly staff evaluation process
